article:
{{Infobox disease
| Name = Eating disorder Image = ICD10 = ICD9 = MeshID = D001068
}}

'Eating disorders' are conditions defined by abnormal eating habits that may
involve either insufficient or excessive food intake to the detriment of an
individual's physical and mental health. Bulimia nervosa and anorexia nervosa
are the most common specific forms in the United Kingdom. Other types of eating disorders include binge eating
disorder and eating disorder not otherwise specified. Bulimia nervosa is a
disorder characterized by binge eating and purging. Purging can include self-
induce vomiting, over-exercising, and the usage of diuretics, enemas, and
laxatives. Anorexia nervosa is characterized by extreme food restriction to the
point of self-starvation and excessive weight loss. [http://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/anorexia-
nervosa, "Anorexia Nervosa"] Nationaleatingdisorders.org. Retrieved 2013-02-
13. Though primarily thought of as affecting females (an estimated
5â10 million being affected in the U.K.), eating disorders affect males as
well. An estimated 10 â 15% of people with eating disorders are males
(Gorgan, 1999). (an estimated 1 million U.K. males being
affected). Although eating disorders are
increasing all over the world among both men and women, there is evidence to
suggest that it is women in the Western world who are at the highest risk of
developing them and the degree of westernization increases the
risk. Cummins, L.H. & Lehman, J. 2007. 40% of eating disorder cases are
diagnosed in females ages 15-19 years old (Hoe van Hoeken, 2003). Eating
Disorders and Body Image Concerns in Asian American Women: Assessment and
Treatment from a Multi-Cultural and Feminist Perspective. Eating Disorders. 15.
pp217-230. Nearly half of all Americans personally know someone with an
eating disorder. The skill to comprehend the central processes of appetite has
increased tremendously since leptin was discovered, and the skill to observe the
functions of the brain as well. Interactions between motivational,
homeostatic and self-regulatory control processes are involved in eating
behaviour, which is a key component in eating disorders.

The precise cause of eating disorders is not entirely understood, but there is
evidence that it may be linked to other medical conditions and situations.
Cultural idealization of thinness and youthfulness have contributed to eating
disorders affecting diverse populations. One study showed that girls with ADHD
have a greater chance of getting an eating disorder than those not affected by
ADHD. Girls With ADHD Are at Increased Risk for
Eating Disorders and Depression [http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/565526
Medline Article] Another study suggested that women with PTSD, especially
due to sexually related trauma, are more likely to develop anorexia
nervosa. One study showed that foster girls are more likely to
develop bulimia nervosa. Some think that peer pressure and idealized
body-types seen in the media are also a significant factor. Some research show
that for certain people there are genetic reasons why they may be prone to
developing an eating disorder. Recent studies
have found evidence a correlation between patients with bulimia nervosa and
substance use disorders. In addition, anxiety disorders and personality
disorders are common occurrences with clients of eating
disorders. Lilenfeld, L.R. et al.,
[http://archpsyc.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=204016 "Bulimia Nervosa:
Psychiatric Disorders in First-Degree Relatives and Effects of Proband
Comorbidity"], Arch Gen Psychiatry, Retrieved 2013-02-14.

While proper treatment can be highly effective for many suffering from specific
types of eating disorders, the consequences of eating disorders can be severe,
including death (whether from direct medical
effects of disturbed eating habits or from comorbid conditions such as suicidal
thinking).
categories: Behavioural syndromes associated with physiological disturbances and physical factors
